section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Martin Jenkins and illustrated by Richard Jones
section-block.rac_book_summary: If you built a new house for your family, what would you build? We’ll see Bird build a nest for her family and think about forces like pushing and pulling.

section-block.rac_body-text: Tell an addition number story totaling less than 5. Use Connecting Cubes to model the problem. Count the cubes and say the total.
Gather the subitizing number cards (dots, lines, fingers). Show each card for one second. Have children call out the number shown. Encourage children to answer quickly.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week, we will read Bird Builds a Nest by Martin Jenkins and illustrated by Richard Jones. What do you think the book will be about? What is a nest?
Lala loves reading stories like this one that also teach information.
Think about this question as we read and then we’ll talk about it:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What did Bird need to do to build her nest?

section.rac_body-text: Focus on Measurement: As you read, point out opportunities to informally compare weight.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why does Bird pull on the worm? Why doesn’t pulling help her get the first worm?
Uh oh. These twigs are too heavy. Can Bird fly with them? What happens when you try to carry something heavy?
Now we see what Bird is doing—she’s building a nest! Why does Bird push and pull the twigs?
What is Bird looking for now? Why does she need soft things?
What is the nest waiting for?
Bird lays eggs in her nest. The eggs will grow into baby birds.
Let’s talk about the guiding question: What did Bird need to do to build her nest?
section.rac_body-text: Guide children to Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask children to share their responses.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Bird needed to push and pull.
Bird needed to find soft things.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about building animal or human homes as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why did Bird need to find twigs?
Bird needed to find twigs to build her n___ (nest).
Bird needed to find twigs to build her nest.
How did Bird use the materials she found?

section-block.rac_child_development_hed-green: Child Development: Concrete and Pictorial Models
section-block.rac_child_development_body: Using concrete materials or pictorial models creates a tangible understanding of an abstract concept, such as math. Models can be used to help children add and subtract numbers using objects, such as counters. By using concrete or pictorial models, children start to develop an understanding of abstract mathematical concepts.

section-block.rac_body-text: Ask children how they know when they have a problem. Discuss what kinds of problems they can solve on their own and which problems need an adult to help. Explain and practice strategies like trading or taking turns as a way to compromise and resolve conflicts.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the story Bird Builds a Nest by Martin Jenkins and illustrated by Richard Jones. We will think about how Bird solves a problem.
Clifford loves to see how other animals solve problems in stories like this one!

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Focus on Operations: As you read, point out places children can add or subtract from a total, using their fingers or Connecting Cubes.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Bird finds one worm, but the worm is too big and strong for her to pull. What is Bird’s problem right now? (MB)
How does Bird solve the problem she had with the first worm being too big? Did she need help to solve her problem? (MB)
Now Bird has a new problem. What is her new problem? How do you think she’ll solve it? (MB)
How did Bird solve her problem? (MB)
Let’s find out how many twigs Bird carries here. We’ll use one Connecting Cube for each twig.
section.rac_body-text: Model using one Connecting Cube to represent the large twig and two cubes to represent the medium-sized twigs. Count aloud to find the total. Repeat by adding three or four more cubes representing small twigs.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why does Bird keep flying back and forth? Why doesn’t she just carry all the sticks at once? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Use found objects and other classroom supplies to allow children to build or draw their own birds’ nests.

After they finish creating their nests, give children five or fewer Connecting Cubes to represent eggs. Encourage them to tell number stories about Bird’s eggs. For example, Bird laid two eggs. She flew away and then laid one more egg. Now she has three eggs.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about a problem and solution.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Provide children with language they could use to solve problems. Guide children to role play how they would respond if someone grabbed a toy from them. Instead of getting upset, you could calmly say, “I am playing with that.” Encourage children to engage in conflict resolution like this without adult help. (https://www.scholastic.com/teachers/articles/teaching-content/ages-stages-learning-resolve-conflicts/)

section-block.rac_body-text: Share classroom objects that are heavy and light. Choose different-sized objects and point out that size is not directly related to weight.
Tell children the dots on the subitizing Number Cards are eggs in a birds’ nest. Show the cards in a random order and have children call out how many eggs they see.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread Bird Builds a Nest by Martin Jenkins and illustrated by Richard Jones. We will talk about how birds use heavy and light materials to build their nests.
Lala loves reading stories that also teach true information.
We know that different animals build different kinds of homes. As we read today, think about this question:

section.rac_body-text: Focus on Measurement: As you read, point out words related to the weight of objects.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What is the problem with the heavy sticks? What happens if something is too heavy for you to carry?
The twigs on these pages are good for Bird. They are smaller. What about the smaller twigs might make them easier to carry?
Bird found softer materials that are very light. Is it easier to pick up something light or heavy?
Bird pushes the light feathers and leaves into the nest to make it smooth and soft. Why does she add soft things on the inside of the nest? How does it feel to sit on a soft chair?
Now there are two birds in the nest. What are they waiting for?
Did you listen and remember as we read the story today? What makes Bird’s nest cozy?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to respond to the guiding question. Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Bird worked hard to put the twigs in place.
Bird added soft, light things to the inside of the nest.
Bird pushed the sides to make them smooth and soft.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write a measurement story about heavy and light objects.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How do the feathers and grass help make the nest cozy?
The feathers and grass make the nest feel s___ (soft).
The feathers and grass make the nest feel soft.
Why does Bird want the nest to be cozy?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Most communication is nonverbal. Exaggerating nonverbal cues as you teach vocabulary is a way to help multilingual learners. For example, when you teach heavy, weigh your arms down and sag as you say the word. As you discuss which items are heavy, repeat these nonverbal cues.

section-block.rac_body-text: Give each child two items of different weights, such as one Connecting Cube and one block. Have them hold one in each hand and compare. Which is heavier?
Have children pretend to be rabbits carrying light things—they easily hop up and down. Then have them act like rabbits carrying heavy things and flop down to the ground.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read The Three Little Rabbits. It is the story of three rabbits building houses.
Lala loves stories about building things.

Bird Builds a Nest is about a Bird building a nest with twigs and feathers. The Three Little Rabbits is about rabbits building houses with straw, sticks, and bricks. Let’s see what we can learn about building a strong house!
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show the Bird Builds a Nest cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How do we build things?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart stopping to ask questions. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to respond.
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: He made a house of straw.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What did Ryan Rabbit use to build his house? Do you think straw is heavy or light?
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: He made a house of sticks.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What material did Ricardo Rabbit use to build her house? Do you think sticks are heavy or light?
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: She made a house of bricks.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What material did Rebecca Rabbit use to build his house? Do you think bricks are heavy or light?
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: He blew the straw house down.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do you think it would be easy or hard to blow away something light like straw? Why?
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: He could not blow the brick house down.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Would it be easy or hard to blow away a brick building? Why?
How did the brick house solve the rabbits’ problem with the wolf? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Present a variety of materials for building a house, including blocks, books, pieces of paper, pipe cleaners, playing cards, and magnetic tiles.
As a class, discuss the merits of each building material. Have children work in groups to build a house with the material of their choice. After, discuss the strength of each house.
Provide a writing prompt about building and give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Expanding children’s vocabulary with academic terms opens up possibilities to children both in school and outside. Encourage children to use academic vocabulary they have learned throughout the day and in different contexts. Remind them that when they hear terms they do not know, they can ask what the words mean, including outside of school.

section-block.rac_body-text: Point out the ways Bird pushes and pulls materials in the book. Ask children to provide more examples of pushing and pulling from life.
Sing a version of “Row, Row, Row Your Boat” with children using build a nest/build it out of sticks/cozily/ make it nice for chicks. As you sing, act out building a nest like Bird.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell Bird Builds a Nest by Martin Jenkins and illustrated by Richard Jones.
Lala likes stories that help her learn new information!
We saw that Bird found and used twigs, feathers, and leaves to build her cozy nest. As we read the story today, think about this guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Why did Bird build a nest?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread the book one more time together. This time, we will act like Bird and notice what is heavy and light.
Bird eats worms for breakfast. She pulls hard to get worms out of the ground. Let’s pretend to pull worms out of the ground. It’s hard!
Bird needs light sticks to build her nest. Why do they need to be light?
Let’s pretend to carry as many twigs as we can. Can you carry three? Can you carry two more? How many would you be carrying in all?
Bird pushes and pulls all the twigs to turn them into her nest. Are heavy or light things easier to push and pull? Let’s push and pull on imaginary twigs!
Now let’s pretend to carry feathers and dried grass. We can carry a lot more because these are light! Why does Bird want soft building materials for her nest?
Bird has been getting the nest ready. There were no eggs, and now there are five! Let’s pretend to curl up in our cozy nests.
Let’s talk about the guiding question. Why did Bird build a nest?
section.rac_body-text: Ask children to Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to choose several children to share their responses.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: She built a nest to have a cozy place to live.
She built a nest to hold her eggs.
She built a nest for her family.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about a house they wish to build and what materials they’d use.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who is Bird building the nest for?
Bird is building the nest for her e___ (eggs).
Bird is building the nest for her eggs.
A nest is a house. Why do we build houses?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Preschool children mostly think of weight informally: they estimate which of two objects is harder to push and pull, they ask themselves which feels heavier in their hands, and, often, they guess by just looking at the objects. When discussing the weight of objects, remind children that weight is determined by material and size.
